Journal.Title: Huan jing ke xue= Huanjing kexue

Article.ArticleTitle: [Characteristic of Surface Ozone and Meteorological Parameters Analysis in Anyang City].

AbstractText: This study uses the national ambient air quality station data of Anyang City from 2014 to 2017 to analyze the characteristics and variation rules of ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) in different functional zones (urban, suburban, and industrial), and also studies meteorological influencing factors and potential source distributions of O<sub>3</sub> pollution. The results showed that the O<sub>3</sub> concentration in Anyang increased significantly between 2014 and 2017, whereby pollution started to advance from 2015 and the earliest occurrence of an O<sub>3</sub> pollution episode was in April 2017. The 90<sup>th</sup> percentile and average concentrations of O<sub>3</sub> in the industrial zone increased at faster rates (average annual growth of 16.0 μg·m<sup>-3</sup> and 13.0 μg·m<sup>-3</sup>, respectively) than of those in the urban and suburban zones. The O<sub>3</sub> concentrations at the suburban site showed the fastest increase of all zones at the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile (average annual growth of 13.2 μg·m<sup>-3</sup>). The monthly variation in O<sub>3</sub> concentrations in Anyang showed an "M" pattern that varied spatially depending on the zone. Temperature played a leading role in O<sub>3</sub> concentrations; air temperatures >23℃, relative humidity <58%, and a wind speed of 5 m·s<sup>-1</sup> in a south-southwesterly direction were closely related to the occurrence of high O<sub>3</sub> concentrations. Potential sources of O<sub>3</sub> in different seasons were significantly different, and mainly distributed in southern Hebei, northern Hubei, and northern Shenyang in summer. The first heavy O<sub>3</sub> pollution day in the studied period was in May 2017, at which time the highest O<sub>3</sub> concentration was found in the industrial zone (up to 405 μg·m<sup>-3</sup>). This heavy O<sub>3</sub> pollution episode was related to the continuous high temperature that was caused by the transfer of a dry, hot air mass in western China.
